p: At least one person in the USA who had a high-risk laboratory exposure to Nipah virus has received the experimental neutralizing monoclonal antibody (termed m102.4) against the Nipah viral glycoprotein G, on an emergency use basis ( Broder et al., 2016). In Australia, an equine vaccine against the closely-related Hendra henipavirus to prevent infection in horses has been licensed since 2015 ( Broder et al., 2016).
